comments.content: Look hand-drawn to me, as all repeating letters look different (2 /f, 2 /u, 2/l).

Released in 1948 in the era of great show-card lettering.  
Compare your first image with this style sample for lettering artists:

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803005736im_/http:/typophile.com/files/LoadedBrushScript2_4959.jpg)
  
There are quite a few digitized brush script fonts but none is a perfect match. The closest I was able to find to the tone and general feel of your first image is Signalist by Mike Melvas:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mika-melvas/signalist/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803005736/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/mika-melvas/signalist/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/mika-melvas/signalist/")  
There are also two fairly close fonts from Filmotype:  
Filmotype Lakeside:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lakeside/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803005736/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lakeside/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lakeside/")  
and  
Filmotype Lasalle:  
 [http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lasalle/](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803005736/http:/www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lasalle/ "http://www.myfonts.com/fonts/filmotype/lasalle/")  
Lasalle is also available from Scangraphic and Elsner+Flake.  
BTW the lettering artists for Unfaithfully Yours were busy. They also produced a third version of the movie title:  

 ![](http://web.archive.org/web/20140803005736im_/http:/typophile.com/files/UnfaithfullyYours1948_4_4669.jpg)
  
Don
